articles.headline: Cadillac Tries to Make a Fresh Start in New York
articles.snippet: General Motors is seeking to help the brand shed its stodgy image and recapture a mystique that melted away nearly two decades ago.
articles.abstract: General Motors is seeking to help the brand shed its stodgy image and recapture a mystique that melted away nearly two decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time Cadillac, a symbol of American success, was the top-selling luxury car brand in the United States was in 1997. Since then, its executives have tried seemingly everything — from new models to new management to new marketing — to revive its flagging fortunes, with little to show for it.

articles.headline: Obama Presses Chinese on Global Warming
articles.snippet: President Obama, emboldened by his use of executive powers to fight climate change at home, challenged China to make the same effort to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.
articles.abstract: President Obama, emboldened by his use of executive powers to fight climate change at home, challenged China to make the same effort to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama, emboldened by his use of executive powers to fight climate change at home, challenged China on Tuesday to make the same effort to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions and join a worldwide campaign to curb global warming.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: The Benefits of Easing Climate Change
articles.snippet: For all the fears that curbing carbon emissions will put the brakes on economic growth, it might actually enhance it.
articles.abstract: For all the fears that curbing carbon emissions will put the brakes on economic growth, it might actually enhance it.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, more than 100 world leaders gathered at the United Nations to open a climate summit meeting that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon hopes will provide momentum to a new round of negotiations toward a global environmental agreement to be signed in Paris next year.

articles.headline: Companies Take the Baton in Climate Change Efforts
articles.snippet: Forty companies pledged on Tuesday to help cut tropical deforestation in half by 2020 and stop it entirely by 2030.
articles.abstract: Forty companies pledged on Tuesday to help cut tropical deforestation in half by 2020 and stop it entirely by 2030.
articles.lead_paragraph: With political efforts to slow global warming moving at a tortuous pace, some of the world’s largest companies are stepping into the void, pledging more support for renewable energy, greener supply chains and fresh efforts to stop the destruction of the world’s tropical forests.

articles.headline: For High School Football Coaches and Fans, a New Digital Blitz
articles.snippet: Several websites and apps are transforming the way that players and coaches practice, scout other teams and analyze their own performance.
articles.abstract: Several websites and apps are transforming the way that players and coaches practice, scout other teams and analyze their own performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Time for some Texas high school football, heavily assisted by modern technology.

articles.headline: Where Profit Margins Are Hefty, Online Upstarts Muscle In
articles.snippet: E-commerce companies see opportunities in selling products as varied as mattresses and eyeglasses, where established companies are accustomed to plump profit margins.
articles.abstract: E-commerce companies see opportunities in selling products as varied as mattresses and eyeglasses, where established companies are accustomed to plump profit margins.
articles.lead_paragraph: Venture capitalists see opportunity in facial stubble.

articles.headline: New Rules Make Inversions Less Lucrative, Experts Say
articles.snippet: The changes by the Treasury Department will not stop the deals but may make some more difficult to execute, corporate advisers said.
articles.abstract: The changes by the Treasury Department will not stop the deals but may make some more difficult to execute, corporate advisers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inversions, the hottest deal structure on Wall Street, appear to be safe for now. But they just became less profitable and more difficult to pull off.

articles.headline: Wall St. Bankrolls Ex-Executive as He Sues Over A.I.G. Bailout
articles.snippet: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief of A.I.G., has now raised several million dollars from three Wall Street investors to help cover the cost of the case.
articles.abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief of A.I.G., has now raised several million dollars from three Wall Street investors to help cover the cost of the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: One might call it “chutzpah,” as several irate lawmakers did, or “rubbing salt in the wounds” of the American taxpayer. But to a few Wall Street financiers, a lawsuit that accuses the government of shortchanging the American International Group in its 2008 bailout is something else: a promising investment in a cause they support.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: Europe’s Anti-Semitism Comes Out of the Shadows
articles.snippet: In the wake of the conflict in Gaza, three communities became flash points of violence and began contending with hatred they thought was buried in the past.
articles.abstract: In the wake of the conflict in Gaza, three communities became flash points of violence and began contending with hatred they thought was buried in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARCELLES, France — From the immigrant enclaves of the Parisian suburbs to the drizzly bureaucratic city of Brussels to the industrial heartland of Germany, Europe’s old demon returned this summer. “Death to the Jews!” shouted protesters at pro-Palestinian rallies in Belgium and France. “Gas the Jews!” yelled marchers at a similar protest in Germany.

articles.headline: Under New Leadership, BlackBerry Unveils the Passport, Its Newest Smartphone
articles.snippet: The company, whose chief executive, John S. Chen, arrived in November, is hoping that the new Passport phone will put BlackBerry back on the board, even if only modestly.
articles.abstract: The company, whose chief executive, John S. Chen, arrived in November, is hoping that the new Passport phone will put BlackBerry back on the board, even if only modestly.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — There are plenty of signs suggesting that John S. Chen, chief executive of BlackBerry, should sprint as fast as possible away from making phones.

articles.headline: In U.N. Speech, Obama Vows to Fight ISIS ‘Network of Death’
articles.snippet: President Obama on Wednesday charted a muscular new course for the United States in a turbulent world that includes threats by the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Wednesday charted a muscular new course for the United States in a turbulent world that includes threats by the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama on Wednesday charted a muscular new course for the United States in a turbulent world, telling the United Nations General Assembly in a bluntly worded speech that the American military would work with allies to dismantle the Islamic State’s “network of death” and warning Russia that it would pay for its bullying of Ukraine.
